revision.comment: Undid revision 521013164 by [[Special:Contributions/118.166.221.245|118.166.221.245]] ([[User talk:118.166.221.245|talk]]) see [[Retrocession Day]] and reference number 52 at [[History of Taiwan]]
revision.text:
{{Redirect|GiE}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} A '''government in exile''' is a political group which claims to be a [[Sovereign state|country]]'s legitimate [[government]], but is unable to exercise legal power and instead resides in a foreign country.{{cite web|url=http://wordnetweb.princeton.edu/perl/webwn?s=government-in-exile |title=Princeton University WordNet |publisher=Wordnetweb.princeton.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} Governments in [[exile]] usually plan to one day return to their native country and regain formal power. A government in exile differs from a [[rump state]] in the sense that a rump state controls at least part of its former territory.Tir, J. , 2005-02-22 "Keeping the Peace After Secessions: Territorial Conflicts Between Rump and Secessionist States" Paper presented at the annual meeting of the International Studies Association, Hilton Hawaiian Village, Honolulu, Hawaii Online <.PDF>. 2009-05-25 from [http://www.allacademic.com/meta/p72056_index.html allacademic.com]{{dead link|date=September 2012}} For example, during [[World War I]], nearly all of [[Belgium]] was [[Military occupation|occupied]] by [[German Empire|Germany]], but Belgium and its allies held on to a small slice in the country's west. A government in exile, conversely, has lost all its territory. Governments in exile frequently occur during [[war]]time occupation, or in the aftermath of a [[civil war]], [[revolution]], or [[Coup d'état|military coup]]. For example, during German expansion in [[World War II]], some [[Europe]]an governments sought refuge in the [[United Kingdom]], rather than face destruction at the hands of [[Nazi Germany]]. A government in exile may also form from widespread belief in the illegitimacy of a ruling government.For instance, the [[Syrian National Council]] was formed as a result of the [[Syrian Civil War]], which sought to end the rule of the ruling [[Ba'ath Party]]. The effectiveness of a government in exile depends primarily on the amount of external support it can receive, either from foreign governments or from the population of its own country. Some governments in exile develop into a formidable force, posing a serious challenge to the [[incumbent]] [[regime]] of the country, while others are maintained chiefly as a symbolic gesture. The phenomenon of a government in exile predates formal use of the term. In periods of [[Monarch|monarchical government]], exiled monarchs or dynasties sometimes set up exile courts—as the [[House of Stuart]] did when driven from their throne by [[Oliver Cromwell]] and at the [[Glorious Revolution]], or the [[House of Bourbon]] did during the [[French Revolution]] and the rule of [[Napoleon]]. With the spread of [[constitutional monarchy]], monarchical governments in exile started to include a [[prime minister]].{{example needed|date=May 2012}} ==Activities== [[International law]] recognizes that governments in exile may undertake many types of actions in the conduct of their daily affairs. These actions include: * becoming a party to a bilateral or international [[treaty]] * amending or revising its own [[constitution]] * maintaining [[military forces]] * retaining, or newly obtaining, [[diplomatic recognition]] from other states * issuing [[Identity document|identity cards]] * allowing the formation of new [[Political party|political parties]] * holding [[election]]s In cases where a host country holds a large [[expatriate]] population from a government in exile's home country, or an [[Ethnic group|ethnic]] population from that country, the government in exile might come to exercise some administrative functions within such a population. For example, the WWII [[Provisional Government of Free India]] had such authority among the [[Malaysian Indian|ethnically Indian]] population of [[British Malaya]], with the consent of the then [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] military authorities. ==Current governments in exile== Governments in exile may have [[List of states with limited recognition|little or no recognition from other states]]. Some exiled governments have some characteristics in common with [[rump state]]s. Such disputed or partially in exile cases are noted in the tables below. ===Deposed governments of current states=== These governments in exile were created by [[Deposition (politics)|deposed]] governments or rulers who continue to claim legitimate authority of the state they once controlled. {|class="sortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:25%;"|Name ! style="width:3%;"|Exile since ! style="width:17%;" class="unsortable"|State controlling its claimed territory (''entirely or partially'') ! style="width:51%;" class="unsortable"|Notes ! style="width:4%;" class="unsortable"|References |- | {{flagicon|Belarus|1991}} [[Belarusian People's Republic]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1920 | {{flag|Belarus|name=Republic of Belarus}} | The oldest current government in exile, currently led by [[Ivonka Survilla]] in [[Toronto]], in a council of 14 called the [[Rada]]; see also [[History of Belarus]] | align=center| {{cite web|url=http://www.radabnr.org/indexen.html |title=Official website of the Belarusian National Republic |publisher=Radabnr.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | [[File:Flag of Persia (1910).svg|25px]] [[Qajar dynasty]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1925 | {{flag|Iran|name=Islamic Republic of Iran}} | The [[Qajar dynasty]] went into exile in 1923 and continue to claim the Iranian throne, which is currently claimed by [[Mohammad Hassan Mirza II]] who is based in [[Dallas, Texas]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Burma|1948}} [[National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1990 | {{flag|Myanmar|name= Republic of the Union of Myanmar}} | Currently led by [[Sein Win]] and composed of members of [[Pyidaungsu Hluttaw|parliament]] elected in 1990 but not allowed by the [[Tatmadaw|military]] to take office; based in [[Rockville, Maryland|Rockville]], [[Maryland]], [[United States]] | align=center| |- | [[File:Naval flag of Iran 1933-1980.svg|25px]] [[Pahlavi dynasty]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1979 | {{flag|Iran|name=Islamic Republic of Iran}} | The [[Pahlavi dynasty]], led by [[Reza Pahlavi]] and living in [[Potomac, Maryland]]; see also [[Iranian Revolution]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Laos|1952}} [[Royal Lao Government in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1975 | {{flag|Lao People's Democratic Republic}} | The former government of the [[Kingdom of Laos]]; based in [[Paris]] | align=center| |- | {{flag|Republic of China}}
(disputed due mainly to the controversial [[political status of Taiwan]] ) | style="text-align:center;"| 1949 | {{flag|Afghanistan|name=Islamic Republic of Afghanistan}}
{{flag|Bhutan|name=Kingdom of Bhutan}}
{{flag|People's Republic of China}}
'''{{flag|Republic of China}}''' itself
{{flag|India|name=Republic of India}}
{{flag|Japan}}
{{flag|Mongolia}}
{{flag|Myanmar|name=Republic of the Union of Myanmar}}
{{flag|Pakistan|name=Islamic Republic of Pakistan}}
{{flag|Russian Federation}}
{{flag|Tajikistan|name=Republic of Tajikistan}} | The Republic of China (ROC) is the state which governs [[Taiwan]] and some of its [[List of islands of the Republic of China|surrounding islands]].{{Cite book|last=Henckaerts|first=Jean-Marie|title=The international status of Taiwan in the new world order: legal and political considerations|year=1996|publisher=Kluwer Law International|isbn=90-411-0929-3|page=337|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=_9kuVIayxDoC&pg=PA118&dq=Republic+of+China+sovereign+state&hl=en&ei=qyWuTI7xBoeWswa3t7i5DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFAQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Republic%20of%20China%20sovereign%20state&f=false|quote = p117. "The ROC joined the United Nations in 1945 as a Charter member and was until 1971 one of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The ROC membership in the United Nations continued to exist through 1971 despite the fact that the ROC government lost the Chinese mainland and moved to Taiwan in 1949. The reduction of a huge area under its effective control in 1949 did not eliminate the very existence of the ROC as a sovereign state as defined by international law. In short, the ROC government has continued to exercise its sovereignty over territories under its effective control since 1912. It has never disappeared from the world as a sovereign state."
p118. "President Harry S. Truman of the United States stated on January 5, 1950 that 'Taiwan was surrendered to ... Chiang Kai-Shek, and for the past four years, the United States and the other Allied Powers have accepted the exercise of the Chinese authority over the island.'"
p118.-119. "The Republic of China is, by any standard, a political entity, recognized by 29 countries as of today. It has a defined territory, with Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu together with its population of 21 million, under its effective control ever since 1945 or earlier. ...
The Republic of China indeed is a sovereign state as defined by the Montevideo Convention on the Rights and Duties of States of 1933. It also complies with the definition as 'state' defined by current theory of international law, as discussed in the Restatement (Third) of the Foreign Relations Law of the United States of 1987."}} Its status as a government in exile is disputed. {{Cite news|title=Tsai blasted for R.O.C. legitimacy remark|url=http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national-news/2010/05/27/258201/Tsai-blasted.htm|newspaper=China Post|date=27 May 2010|accessdate=12 June 2010}}{{Cite news|title=Treaty confirmed sovereignty: Ma|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2009/04/29/2003442293|accessdate=14 June 2010|newspaper=Taipei Times|date=29 April 2009}}{{cite web | author = Kerry Dumbaugh (Specialist in Asian Affairs Foreign Affairs, Defense, and Trade Division) | title = Taiwan’s Political Status: Historical Background and Ongoing Implications | publisher = Congressional Research Service | url = http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:NhvZCrb8NXkJ:fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/64794.pdf+Congressional+Research+Service+Report+RS22388&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgeH4MCQxphwU3lnhP3Rgf5W7CTDRmNredoBazcx9QZb7wFOuoaqq43CjT5xD54tlnmFK6Gp1rV8dpiqgh8esxb_jdVjlWtCT84p7-Bryun69QoMgfPzuohYPUsoH1J_wBvDHDK&sig=AHIEtbS6cTCYiceVtiHn0z52yXq1HWU-mA | date = 23 February 2006 | accessdate = 20 December 2009 | quote = While on October 1, 1949, in Beijing a victorious Mao proclaimed the creation of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), Chiang Kai-shek re-established a temporary capital for his government in Taipei, Taiwan, declaring the ROC still to be the legitimate Chinese government-in-exile and vowing that he would “retake the mainland” and drive out communist forces.}}{{cite web | author = [http://www.heritage.org/about/staff/JohnTkacik.cfm John J. Tkacik, Jr.] | title = Taiwan's "Unsettled" International Status: Preserving U.S. Options in the Pacific | publisher = Heritage Foundation | url = http://www.heritage.org/Research/asiaandthepacific/bg2146.cfm | date = 19 June 2008 | accessdate = 20 December 2009 | quote = Chiang Kai-shek wanted to fight it out on an all-or-nothing basis. There are also reports that Chiang's advisors convinced him that if the ROC mission stayed to represent Taiwan, Chiang would be under pressure to demonstrate in some constitutional way that his Chinese government-in-exile represented the people of Taiwan rather than the vast population of China. Doing so would require Chiang to dismantle his existing regime (which was elected in 1947 on the Chinese mainland and continued to rule in Taiwan under emergency martial law provisions without benefit of elections), adopt an entirely new constitu­tion, and install an entirely new government.}}{{cite web|title=ROC Government in Exile Is Illogical (English transl.)|url=http://www.kmt.org.tw/english/page.aspx?type=article&mnum=115&anum=8153|date=June 1, 2010|publisher=(original source: [http://www.nownews.com/2010/06/01/142-2609610.htm "「流亡政府」邏輯不通" by NOWnews Network])|accessdate=7 October 2010}}TIME magazine, Far Eastern Economic Review, Stanford University, US State Dept., Public Broadcasting Service, BBC, US Congressional Research Service, UK Parliament, UK Foreign Office, Los Angeles Times, New York Times, and numerous law journals have all referred to the Republic of China on Taiwan as a government in exile. However, the ROC is recognised as the legitimate government of China by {{Numrec|ROC||UN member states}} and the [[Holy See]]. The [[PRC]] claims that the ROC government no longer exists. {{Citation |url=http://www.taiwanbasic.com/taiwanus/rocinexile.htm |title=Republic of China government in exile |accessdate=2010-02-27}}{{Citation |url=http://www.asil.org/ajil/chinatai.htm |title=Resolving Cross-Strait Relations Between China and Taiwan |authors=Jonathan I. Charney and J. R. V. Prescott |publisher=American Journal of International Law |date = July 2000|accessdate=2011-02-28 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20040622182920/http://www.asil.org/ajil/chinatai.htm |archivedate = 2004-06-22}} Proponents of this view argue that because [[Taiwan]] is not a part of the Republic of China, the ROC is located in foreign territory, therefore effectively making it a government in exile.{{Citation |url=http://www.taiwanbasic.com/historical/starr.htm |title=Starr Memorandum of the Dept. of State |author=Robert I. Starr |date=July 13, 1971 |quote=Following World War II, the Republic of China, under the Kuomintang (KMT) became the governing polity on Taiwan. In 1949, after losing control of mainland China following the Chinese civil war, the ROC government under the KMT withdrew to occupied Taiwan and Chiang Kai-shek declared martial law. Japan formally renounced all territorial rights to Taiwan in 1952 in the San Francisco Peace Treaty, but neither in that treaty nor in the peace treaty signed between Japan and China was the territorial sovereignty of Taiwan awarded to the Republic of China. |accessdate=2012-05-18}} Opponents claim that Taiwan is part the ROC, and the government is still located in its own territory, qualifying it not as a government in exile but as a [[rump state]]. For further information, see [[Political status of Taiwan]], [[Legal status of Taiwan]], and [[Chinese Civil War]]. | |} ===Exiled governments of non-self-governing or occupied territories=== These governments in exile are governments of [[Self-governance|non-self-governing]] or occupied territories. They claim legitimate authority over a territory they once controlled, or claim legitimacy of a [[Decolonization|post-decolonization]] authority. The claim may stem from an exiled group's election as a legitimate government. The [[United Nations]] recognizes the [[right of self-determination]] for the population of these territories, including the possibility of establishing independent sovereign states. {|class="unsortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:25%;"|Name ! style="width:3%;"|Exile since ! style="width:17%;" class="unsortable"|State controlling its claimed territory (''entirely or partially'') ! style="width:51%;" class="unsortable"|Notes ! style="width:4%;" class="unsortable"|References |- | {{flag|Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic}} | style="text-align:center;"| 1976 | {{flag|Morocco|name=Kingdom of Morocco}}
{{flagicon|Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic}} '''[[Sahrawi Republic]]''' itself | Headquartered in the [[Tindouf]] region of [[Algeria]], controlling what it calls the [[Free Zone (Western Sahara region)|Free Zone]] in the eastern part of [[Western Sahara]]; claims ''[[de jure]]'' sovereignty over the entire territory | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Palestine}} [[State of Palestine]][http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000827/082713EO.pdf Application for the admission of Palestine as a Member of State of UNESCO]: "A government-in-exile, having no effective control in the territory and not having had previous control, ..."[http://web.archive.org/web/20100611201301/http://www.medea.be/index.html?page=2&lang=en&doc=143 PLO Executive Committee]: "The Executive Committee of the PLO, in practice the "government in exile" of the State of Palestine" | style="text-align:center;"| 1988 | {{flag|Israel|name=State of Israel}} | [[Palestinian Declaration of Independence|Unilaterally declared]] in exile in [[Algiers]] by the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] that later established the [[Palestinian National Authority]] interim [[Palestinian territories|territorial]] administration as result of the [[Oslo Accords]] signed by the PLO, Israel, the United States, and [[Russia]]. Currently, ultimate controlIsrael allows the PNA to execute some functions in the [[Palestinian territories]], depending on [[Administrative divisions of the Oslo Accords|special area classification]] with [[Israel's unilateral disengagement plan|minimal interference]] (retaining control of borders: [[national airspace|air]], [http://dissidentvoice.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/12/Gaza-map-08s-fishing-limits-20090119.jpg sea] [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea#UNCLOS III|beyond internal waters]], [[European Union Border Assistance Mission Rafah|land]]) in the [[Gaza strip]] and maximum in "Area C". over all of the territories is exercised by Israel,{{cite web | last = Gold | first = Dore | coauthors = Institute for Contemporary Affairs | title = Legal Acrobatics: The Palestinian Claim that Gaza is Still "Occupied" Even After Israel Withdraws | work = Jerusalem Issue Brief, Vol. 5, No. 3 | publisher = Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs | date = 26 August 2005 | url = http://www.jcpa.org/brief/brief005-3.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-16}}{{cite web | last = Bell | first = Abraham | title = International Law and Gaza: The Assault on Israel's Right to Self-Defense | work = Jerusalem Issue Brief, Vol. 7, No. 29 | publisher = Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs | date = 28 January 2008 | url = http://www.jcpa.org/brief/brief005-3.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-16}}{{Cite press release | title = Address by Foreign Minister Livni to the 8th Herzliya Conference | publisher = Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Israel | date = 22 January 2008 | url = http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Speeches+by+Israeli+leaders/2008/Address+by+FM+Livni+to+the+8th+Herzliya+Conference+22-Jan-2008.htm?DisplayMode=print | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20090624055108/http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Government/Speeches+by+Israeli+leaders/2008/Address+by+FM+Livni+to+the+8th+Herzliya+Conference+22-Jan-2008.htm?DisplayMode=print | archivedate = 2009-06-24 | accessdate = 2010-07-16}}{{cite web | last = Salih | first = Zak M. | title = Panelists Disagree Over Gaza’s Occupation Status | publisher = University of Virginia School of Law | date = 17 November 2005 | url = http://www.law.virginia.edu/html/news/2005_fall/gaza.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-16}}{{cite web | title = Israel: 'Disengagement' Will Not End Gaza Occupation | publisher = Human Rights Watch | date = 29 October 2004 | url = http://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2004/10/29/isrlpa9577.htm | accessdate = 2010-07-16}} but it allows the PNA to execute some functions there, depending on [[Administrative divisions of the Oslo Accords|special area classification]]. The members of the institutions of the State of Palestine meet inside its claimed territory{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/PLO+picks+new+leaders+at+landmark+meeting-a01611977736 |title=PLO picks new leaders at landmark meeting |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2012-09-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/PLO+parliament+elects+new+members-a0206759472 |title=PLO parliament elects new members |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2012-09-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Palestinian+affairs.-a0207706170 |title=Palestinian affairs |publisher=Thefreelibrary.com |date=2009-08-25 |accessdate=2012-09-20}}{{cite web|author=Image Source: www.reuters.com |url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/7997109-abbas-i-will-face-aljazeera/image/61121669-palestinian-president-abbas-attends-a-plo-executive-committee-meeting-in-ramallah |title=Palestinian President Abbas attends a PLO executive committee meeting in Ramallah |publisher=Allvoices.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} without having sovereignty over any part of it.[http://www.haaretz.com/news/palestinian-pm-declaration-of-statehood-just-a-formality-1.4140 Palestinian PM: Declaration of statehood just a formality]: "The Palestinians already declared independence unilaterally on Nov. 15, 1988. The declaration was recognized by dozens of countries, but never implemented on the ground."[http://www.unlimitedtopten.com/2011/01/top-ten-governments-currently-in-exile.html Top Ten Governments Currently In Exile]{{dead link|date=September 2012}}:"The state of Palestine was proclaimed in 1988, but in exile. A declaration of a "State of Palestine" was approved on November 15, 1988, by the Palestinian National Council, the legislative body of the Palestinian Liberation Organization (PLO). The declaration was ignored, and eventually rejected, by the State of Israel. Israel controls the territories since 1967 Six-Day War when it captured them from Egypt and Jordan. Currently, the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) envision the establishment of a State of Palestine to include all the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and East Jerusalem, living in peace with Israel under a democratically elected and transparent government. The PNA, however, does not claim sovereignty over any territory and therefore is not the government of the "State of Palestine" proclaimed in 1988. Enough said."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7254434.stm Palestinians 'may declare state']:"Saeb Erekat, disagreed arguing that the Palestine Liberation Organisation had already declared independence in 1988. "Now we need real independence, not a declaration. We need real independence by ending the occupation. We are not Kosovo. We are under Israeli occupation and for independence we need to acquire independence," | |} ===Deposed governments of subnational territories=== These governments in exile claim legitimacy of autonomous territories of another state and have been created by deposed governments or rulers, who and do not claim [[independence]] as a separate state. {|class="unsortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:25%;"|Name ! colspan="2" style="width:3%;"|Exile ! colspan="2" style="width:17%;" class="unsortable"|Current control of claimed territory ! rowspan="2" style="width:51%;" class="unsortable"|Notes ! rowspan="2" style="width:4%;" class="unsortable"|References |- style="text-align:center;" || since || as || by || as |- | {{flagicon|Georgia}} [[Government of the Autonomous Republic of Abkhazia]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1993 | style="text-align:center;"| autonomous republic | {{flagicon|Abkhazia}} [[Government of the Republic of Abkhazia|Republic of Abkhazia]] | style="text-align:center;"| [[List of states with limited recognition|independent state]] | [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]n provincial government, led by [[Giorgi Baramia]], whose territory is under the control of [[Abkhaz people|Abkhaz]] [[Separatism|separatists]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|South Ossetia}} [[Provisional Administrative Entity of South Ossetia]] | style="text-align:center;"| 2008 | style="text-align:center;"| provisional administrative entity | {{flagicon|South Ossetia}} [[Government of South Ossetia|Republic of South Ossetia]] | style="text-align:center;"| [[List of states with limited recognition|independent state]] | Georgian provincial administration, led by [[Dmitry Sanakoyev]], whose territory is under the control of South Ossetian separatists | align=center| |} ===Alternative governments of current states=== These governments have been created in exile by [[political organisation]]s and [[Opposition (politics)|opposition parties]], aspire to become actual governing authorities or claim to be legal successors to previously deposed governments, and have been created as alternatives to incumbent governments. {|class="sortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:20%;"|Name ! style="width:5%;"|Claimed exile ! style="width:5%;"|Exile proclamation ! style="width:15%;"|Government presently controlling claimed territory ! style="width:50%;"|Notes ! style="width:5%;"|References |- | {{flagicon|Ethiopia|1897}} [[Crown Council of Ethiopia]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1974 | style="text-align:center;"| 1993 | {{flag|Ethiopia|name=Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia}} | Led by Prince [[Ermias Sahle Selassie]] and based in the [[Washington D.C.]] area | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|South Vietnam}} [[Government of Free Vietnam]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1975 | style="text-align:center;"| 1995 | {{flag|Vietnam|name=Socialist Republic of Vietnam}} | Based in [[Garden Grove, California|Garden Grove]], [[California]] and [[Missouri City, Texas|Missouri City]], [[Texas]] United States; since 1995, has claimed to be a continuation of the [[South Vietnam|Republic of Vietnam]] | align=center| {{cite web|url=http://gfvn.org/index.asp |title=Website of the Government of Free Vietnam |publisher=Gfvn.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- coalition of five Iranian opposition political organizations, the largest organization being the [[People's Mujahedin of Iran]] led by [[Maryam Rajavi|Maryam]] and [[Massoud Rajavi]]; based in Paris |align=center|{{cite web|url=http://ncr-iran.org/content/view/6046/ |title=National Council of Resistance of Iran |publisher=Ncr-iran.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Taliban.svg|border}} [[Quetta Shura]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 2001 | {{flag|Afghanistan|name= Islamic Republic of Afghanistan}} | Based in [[Quetta]], [[Pakistan]] as as continuation of the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Equatorial Guinea}} [[Progress Party of Equatorial Guinea]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 2003 | {{flag|Equatorial Guinea|name=Republic of Equatorial Guinea}} | Proclaimed [[Severo Moto Nsá|Severo Moto]] [[List of heads of state of Equatorial Guinea|President of Equatorial Guinea]] in [[Madrid]] | align=center| {{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1023158.stm | work=BBC News | title=Timeline: Equatorial Guinea | date=14 April 2010 | accessdate=4 May 2010}} |- | {{flagicon|Syria|1932}} [[Syrian National Council]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 2011 | {{flag|Syria|name=Syrian Arab Republic}} | Opposes the regime of [[President of Syria|President]] [[Bashir al-Assad]]; based in [[Istanbul]]; has ties to the [[Free Syrian Army]]; see also [[2011 Syrian uprising]]. | align=center| {{cite web|url=http://www.syriancouncil.org/en/mission-statement.html |title=Website of the Syrian National Council |publisher=Syriancouncil.org |date=2011-11-25 |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |} ===Alternative separatist governments of current subnational territories=== {{See also|List of active autonomist and secessionist movements}} These governments have been created in exile by political organisations, opposition parties, and separatist movements, and desire to become the governing authorities of their territories as independent states, or claim to be the successor to previously deposed governments, and have been created as alternatives to incumbent governments. {|class="sortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:20%;"|Name ! style="width:5%;"|Claimed exile ! style="width:5%;"|Exile proclamation ! style="width:15%;"|Government presently controlling claimed territory ! style="width:50%;"|Notes ! style="width:5%;"|References |- | [[File:Flag of South Moluccas.svg|23px|border]] [[Republic of South Maluku]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1950 | style="text-align:center;"| 1950 | {{flag|Indonesia|name=Republic of Indonesia}} | Exiled in the [[Netherlands]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of West Papua.svg}} West Papuan Government in Exile | style="text-align:center;"| 1963 | style="text-align:center;"| 1969 | {{flag|Indonesia|name=Republic of Indonesia}} | Campaigns for an independent [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]]; based in the Netherlands | align=center|{{Cite book|title=Perspectives on Contemporary Ethnic Conflict|author=Saha, Santosh C.|publisher=[[Lexington Books]]|year=2006|page=63 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uqYDX_4XQscC&lpg=PA63&ots=l_57GamiTe&dq=Perspectives%20on%20Contemporary%20Ethnic%20Conflict%20Republic%20of%20West%20Papua&pg=PA63#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=20 May 2011 }}{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of the Stateless Nations: S-Z |last=Minahan |first=James |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2002 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |location=Westport, Connecticut |isbn=978-0-313-32384-3 |page=2055 |page=2241 States, with its leaders in [[London]].
There is a contested claim that it has been succeeded by the [[Caucasus Emirate]]. | align=center|{{cite news |title=Peace-Building From The Bottom: A Case Study Of The North Caucasus |author=Huseyn Aliyev |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/peace-building-from-the-bottom-a-case-study-of-the-north-caucasus-24022011/ |newspaper=Eurasia Review |date=24 February 2011 |accessdate=10 May 2011}} |- | {{flagicon|Serbian Krajina}} [[Republic of Serbian Krajina]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1996 | style="text-align:center;"| 2005 | {{flag|Croatia|name=Republic of Croatia}} | Reconstituted in 2005 in [[Belgrade]], by the remains of the government of the [[Republic of Serbian Krajina]], after Croatian forces pushed out the internationally unrecognized entity in 1995 during [[Operation Storm]] at the end of the [[Croatian War of Independence]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of Koma Komalên Kurdistan.svg}} [[Koma Civakên Kurdistan]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 1998 | {{flag|Turkey|name=Republic of Turkey}} | Aims to create a Kurdish state in Turkey; successor organization of Kurdish parliament in exile | align=center|[http://www.todayszaman.com/newsDetail_getNewsById.action;jsessionid=D1CB9969C3D6F84368ACAB29F06818DA?load=detay&link=173093&newsId=173028] |- | {{flagicon image|Flag_of_The_Federal_Republic_of_Southern_Cameroons.svg|date=May 2010}} [[Ambazonia|Republic of Ambazonia]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 1999 | {{flag|Cameroon|name=Republic of Cameroon}} | Former British territory of Southern Cameroons; declared independence on December 31, 1999 | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.southerncameroonsig.org/ |title=Southerncameroonsig.org |publisher=Southerncameroonsig.org |date=2012-08-20 |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon|Kurdistan}} [[Kurds in Syria|Western Kurdistan Government in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"| — | style="text-align:center;"| 2004 | {{flag|Syrian Arab Republic}} | Aims to create a Kurdish state in Syria; based in London | align=center|[http://www.knc.org.uk/WKGWashingtoninEnglish.pdf KNC.org.uk]{{dead link|date=September 2012}} |- | {{flagicon|East Turkestan}} East Turkistan Government in Exile | style="text-align:center;"| 1949 | style="text-align:center;"| 2004 | {{flag|People's Republic of China}} | Seeking independence for [[Xinjiang]] as [[East Turkestan independence movement|"East Turkestan"]]; based in Washington, DC | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.eastturkistangovernmentinexile.us/about_us.html |title=Eastturkistangovernmentinextile.us |publisher=Eastturkistangovernmentinexile.us |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | [[File:Flag of the Shan State.svg|23px|border]] Interim Government of Federated Shan States | style="text-align:center;"| - | style="text-align:center;"| 2005 | {{flag|Burma|name=Republic of the Union of Myanmar}} | Aims to establish an independent state for the [[Shan people|Shan ethnic group]] | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.tgte-us.org/mission.html |title=The Transnational Government of Tamil Eelam |publisher=Tgte-us.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | [[File:TGTE Logo.jpg|23px|border]] [[Transnational Government of Tamil Eelam]] | style="text-align:center;"| 2009 | style="text-align:center;"| 2010 | {{flag|Sri Lanka}} | Aims to establish an independent state of [[Tamil Eelam]] | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.peacehall.com/news/gb/english/2005/04/200504211050.shtml |title=Peacehalle.com |publisher=Peacehall.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |} ===Exiled Governments with ambiguous status=== These governments have ties to the area(s) they represent, but their claimed status and/or stated aims are sufficiently ambiguous that they could fit into other categories. {|class="unsortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:25%;"|Name ! style="width:3%;"|Exile ! style="width:17%;" class="unsortable"|Current control of claimed territory ! style="width:51%;" class="unsortable"|Notes ! style="width:4%;" class="unsortable"|References |- | {{flagicon|Tibet}} [[Central Tibetan Administration]] | style="text-align:center;"| 1959 | {{flag|People's Republic of China}} | Founded by the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] in [[Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh|Dharamsala]], [[India]] with cooperation of Indian [[Prime Minister]] [[Jawaharlal Nehru]]; see also [[Tibetan sovereignty debate]] and [[Tibetan independence movement]] | align=center|[http://www.tibet.net/en/index.php Tibet.net], {{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/buddhism/people/dalailama_1.shtml |title=Religions - Buddhism: Dalai Lama |publisher=BBC |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon|Afghanistan|Taliban}} [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan]] | style="text-align:center;"| 2001 | {{flagicon|Afghanistan}} [[Islamic Republic of Afghanistan]] | The [[Taliban]] gained control over most of [[Afghanistan]] in the [[War in Afghanistan (1978–present)|Afghan civil war]], but were removed from power in the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|current Afghan war]]. | align=center|http://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/21/world/asia/21quetta.html?_r=1&pagewanted=print, {{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/mar/19/talibanization-spreads-to-southwest-pakistan/?page=2 |title=Taliban shifts to southwest Pakistan |publisher=Washington Times |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}}, http://web.archive.org/web/20110206042924/http://www.understandingwar.org/files/The_Talibans_Campaign_For_Kandahar.pdf |} ==Past governments in exile== {{Expand list|date=June 2009}} {|class="sortable wikitable" style="width: 100%" |- ! style="width:25%;"|Name ! style="width:3%;"|Exiled or created(*) since ! style="width:3%;"|Defunct, reestablished,(*) or integrated(°) since ! style="width:17%;" class="unsortable"|State controlling its claimed territory ! style="width:48%;" class="unsortable"|Notes ! style="width:4%;" class="unsortable"|References |- | {{flagicon|England}} [[Privy Council of England]] | style="text-align:center;"|1649 | style="text-align:center;"|1660* | [[File:Flag of The Commonwealth.svg|22px]] [[Commonwealth of England]] (1649—1653)
[[File:Flag of the Commonwealth (1658-1660).svg|22px]] [[The Protectorate|Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland]] (1653—1659)
[[File:Flag of The Commonwealth.svg|22px]] [[Commonwealth of England]] (1659—1660) |Based for most of the [[Interregnum (England)|Interregnum]] in the [[Spanish Netherlands]] and headed by [[Charles II of England|Charles II]]; actively supported Charles' claim to the thrones of [[Kingdom of England|England]], [[Kingdom of Scotland|Scotland]] and [[Kingdom of Ireland|Ireland]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Bangladesh}} [[Provisional Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh]] | style="text-align:center;"|1971* | style="text-align:center;"|1972° | {{flag|Pakistan}} | Based in [[Kolkata]], [[India]]; led by [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]], who later became [[President of Bangladesh]] | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://mujibnagar.com/index.php/mujibnagar-government/8-some-about-mujibnagar-government |title=Mujibnagar.com |publisher=Mujibnagar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon|Dutch Republic}} [[Government of the Dutch Republic in exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1795 | style="text-align:center;"|1814° | {{flag|Batavian Republic}} | Based in London, and led by [[William V, Prince of Orange]]; ultimately they returned to create the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] | align=center| |- | [[File:Philippines flag 1st official.svg|22px]] [[Philippine Revolution|Philippine Government in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1897 | style="text-align:center;"|1898* | {{flag|Spain|1785}} | Based in [[Hong Kong]], [[Emilio Aguinaldo]] set up a government in exile in the former British colony. A result of the [[Pact of Biak-na-Bato]] | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.mongabay.com/reference/country_profiles/2004-2005/Philippines.html |title=Philippines PROFILE |publisher=Mongabay.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea]] | style="text-align:center;"|1919* | style="text-align:center;"|1948° | {{flag|Empire of Japan}} | Based in [[Shanghai]], and later in [[Chongqing]]; after Japan’s defeat in World War II, President [[Syngman Rhee]] became the first president of the [[First Republic of South Korea]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} [[Czechoslovak government-in-exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1939 | style="text-align:center;"|1945° | {{flag|Czechoslovakia}} | Based in [[Paris]] and later in [[London]], during [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia]]. After defeat of Germany, it took control of [[First Republic of Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovakia]]. | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Algeria|1958}} [[Provisional Government of the Algerian Republic]] | style="text-align:center;"|1958* | style="text-align:center;"|1962* | {{flagicon|France}} [[French Algeria]] ([[France]]) | Established during the latter part of the [[Algerian War of Independence]]; after the war, a compromise agreement with the [[Armée de Libération Nationale]] dissolved it but allowed most of its members to enter the [[People's Democratic Republic of Algeria|post-independence government]] | align=center| |- | [[Image:Bandeira da FNLA.svg|23px|border]] [[Revolutionary Government of Angola in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1962* | style="text-align:center;"|1992° | {{flagicon|Angola}} [[Republic of Angola]] | Based in Kinshasa; its military branch, the [[National Liberation Front of Angola]], was recognized as a political party in 1992 and holds three seats in [[National Assembly of Angola|Angola’s parliament]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Namibia|1991}} Namibian Government in Exile | style="text-align:center;"|1966* | style="text-align:center;"|1989° | {{flag|South Africa|1928}} | Formed after opposition to the [[South Africa under apartheid|apartheid]] [[South Africa]]n administration over [[South-West Africa]], which had been ruled as illegal by the United Nations; in 1990, Namibia achieved independence. | align=center|Colin Leys, John S. Saul, and Susan Brown. ''Namibia's Liberation Struggle: The Two-Edged Sword'' (London: James Currey, 1995). pp. 20-21, 40. |- | {{flagicon|Cambodia|1990}} [[Coalition Government of Democratic Kampuchea]] | style="text-align:center;"|1982* | style="text-align:center;"|1993° | [[Image:Flag Of The State and PR Of Cambodia.svg|23px|border]] [[People's Republic of Kampuchea]] | Established with UN recognition in opposition to the [[Vietnam]]ese-backed government. [[Cambodian parliamentary election, 1993|Elections]] in 1993 brought the reintegration of the exiled government into the newly reconstituted Kingdom of Cambodia. | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Poland}} [[Polish government-in-exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1939* | style="text-align:center;"|1990° | Occupied Poland | Based in Paris, [[Angers]], and London, it opposed [[History of Poland (1939-1945)|German occupied Poland]] and the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[satellite state]], the [[People's Republic of Poland]]; disbanded following the [[Revolutions of 1989|fall of communism in Poland]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Estonia}} [[Estonian Government in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1953* | style="text-align:center;"|1992 | {{flagicon|Estonian SSR}} [[Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic]] | Established in [[Sweden]] by several members of [[National Committee of the Republic of Estonia|Otto Tief's government]]; did not achieve any international recognizion. In fact, it was not recognized even by Estonian diplomatic legations that were seen by western countries as legal representatives of the annexed state. A rival government was created by another group of Estonian exiles in the same year in [[Munich]] but it was short lived. | align=center| {{Cite book|title=Recognition of governments in international law |last=Talmon |first=Stefan |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1998 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location= |isbn=0-19-826573-5 |page=299 |pages= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=scc8EboiJX8C&pg=PA299&dq=%22Estonian+Government+in+Exile%22&ei=UYMwSuPgOo-aMu6TiJUP |accessdate=}} |- | {{flagicon|Spanish Republic}} [[Spanish Republican government in exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1939 | style="text-align:center;"|1977 | {{flag|Spanish State}} | Created after [[Francisco Franco]]'s coup d'état; based in [[Mexico City]] from 1939 to 1946, when it was moved to Paris, where it lasted until Franco's death | align=center| |- | [[Image:Flag of Georgia (1918-1921).svg|23px|border]] [[Government of the Democratic Republic of Georgia in Exile]] | style="text-align:center;"|1921 | style="text-align:center;"|1954 | [[Image:Flag of Georgian SSR.svg|23px|border]] [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic]] | Formed after the [[Soviet invasion of Georgia]] of 1921; based in [[Leuville-sur-Orge]], France | align=center| |- | [[Image:Flag of Ukrainian People's Republic 1917.svg|23px|border]] [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] | style="text-align:center;"|1920 | style="text-align:center;"|1992 | {{flagicon|Ukrainian SSR}} [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]]
{{flagicon|Poland}} [[Second Polish Republic]] {{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} [[Czechoslovak Republic (1918–1938)|Czechoslovak Republic]] {{flag|Kingdom of Romania}} | Organized after the Soviet occupation of Ukraine | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Aceh}} [[Free Aceh Movement|Aceh]] | style="text-align:center;"|1976* | style="text-align:center;"|2005 | {{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Republic of Indonesia]] | Headquartered in Sweden; surrendered its separatist intentions and dissolved its armed wing following the 2005 peace agreement with the [[Politics of Indonesia|Indonesian government]] | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Gabon}} Bongo Doit Partir | style="text-align:center;"|1998 | style="text-align:center;"|2009 | {{flag|Gabon}} | Founded by Daniel Mengara in opposition to president [[Omar Bongo]]; after Bongo's death in June 2009, Mengara returned to Gabon in order to participate in the country's [[Gabonese presidential election, 2009|elections]] | align=center|{{cite web|author=Nom * |url=http://www.bdpgabon.org/articles/2003/04/24/un-gouvernement-en-exil/ |title=Bdpgabon.org |publisher=Bdpgabon.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}}{{cite web|url=http://library.stanford.edu/depts/ssrg/africa/gabon.html |title=Library.stanford.edu |publisher=Library.stanford.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon image|Flag of the Missouri State Guard.svg}} [[Confederate government of Missouri]] | style="text-align:center;"|1861 | style="text-align:center;"|1865 | {{flag|United States of America|1861}} ([[Union (American Civil War)|Union]]) | [[Missouri]] had both Union and Confederate governments, but the Confederate government was exiled, eventually governing out of [[Marshall, Texas]]. | align=center|{{cite web|url=http://www.tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/MM/hem1.html |title=Tshaoline.org |publisher=Tshaonline.org |date=1967-09-20 |accessdate=2012-09-20}} |- | {{flagicon|Kentucky}} [[Confederate government of Kentucky]] | style="text-align:center;"|1861 | style="text-align:center;"|1865 | {{flag|United States of America|1861}} ([[Union (American Civil War)|Union]]) | [[Kentucky]] had both Union and Confederate governments. The Confederate government was soon forced out of the state, and was an exiled government traveling with the Confederate [[Army of Tennessee]], except for during a short return when the [[Confederate States Army|Confederate army]] briefly occupied [[Frankfort, Kentucky|Frankfort]]. | align=center| |- | {{flagicon|Hawaii}} [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] | style="text-align:center;"|1893 | style="text-align:center;"|1895 | {{flagicon|Hawaii}} [[Republic of Hawaii]] | Formed by members of the deposed government of Queen [[Liliuokalani]] of [[Hawaii]]; a [[1895 Counter-Revolution in Hawaii|failed insurgency in 1895]] forced the queen to formally disband the kingdom | align=center| |} ===Sovereign Military Order of Malta=== The [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] may be considered a case of a government in exile, since it is without territory but recognised as a sovereign government by numerous sovereign countries. However, it does not claim to be a sovereign state, rather a "sovereign subject" of international law. In addition, it no longer claims jurisdiction over Malta, and recognises and maintains diplomatic relations with the [[Republic of Malta]]. ===World War II=== Many countries established a government in exile after loss of [[sovereignty]] in connection with [[World War II]]: *[[Belgium]] (invaded 10 May 1940; see [[Pierlot IV Government]]) *[[Czechoslovak government-in-exile]] (established in 1940 by [[Edvard Beneš|Beneš]] and recognised by the British and other United Nations governments) *[[Free French Forces|Free France]], based in [[London, England|London]] (from June 1940 to 1944) *[[Greece]] (invaded 28 October 1940; see [[Greek government in exile]]) *[[Luxembourg]] (invaded 10 May 1940) *Netherlands (invaded 10 May 1940; see [[Dutch government in exile]]) *[[Norway]] (invaded 9 April 1940) *[[Commonwealth of the Philippines|Philippine Commonwealth]] (invaded 9 December 1941) *[[Kingdom of Yugoslavia]] (invaded 6 April 1941) Other exiled leaders in Britain in this time included [[King Zog of Albania]] and [[Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia]]. The [[Provisional Government of Free India]] (1943–45) was established by Indian nationalists in exile during the war; unlike most other governments in exile in this war, it was allied to the [[Axis powers|Axis]] and claimed power over an Allied (specifically, British) territory. A [[Bulgarian government-in-exile|Bulgarian government in exile]] and [[Vichy France]] were also allied with the Axis. ====The Danish exception==== The [[Occupation of Denmark]] (9 April 1940) was administered mainly by the [[Foreign Office (Germany)|German Foreign Office]], contrary to other occupied lands that were under [[Military Administration (Nazi Germany)|military]] or [[Reichskommissariat|civilian administration]]. [[Denmark]] did not establish a government in exile, although there was an Association of Free Danes established in [[London]]. [[Christian X of Denmark|King Christian X]] and his government remained in [[Denmark]], and functioned comparatively independently for the first three years of German occupation. Meanwhile, [[Iceland]], [[Greenland]] and the [[Faroe Islands]] were occupied by [[Allies of World War II|the Allies]], and effectively separated from the Danish crown. (See [[British occupation of the Faroe Islands]], [[Iceland during World War II]], and [[History of Greenland during World War II]].) ===Persian Gulf War=== Following the Iraqi invasion and occupation of [[Kuwait]] on August 2, 1990, [[Sheikh]] [[Jaber Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]] and senior members of his government fled to [[Saudi Arabia]], where they set up a government-in-exile operating out of a luxury hotel in [[Dhahran]]. The Kuwaiti government in exile was far more affluent than most other such governments, having full disposal of the very considerable Kuwaiti assets in western banks—of which it made use to conduct a massive [[propaganda]] campaign denouncing the Iraqi occupation and mobilising public opinion in the West in favor of war with [[Iraq]]. In March 1991, following the American victory in the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]], the Sheikh and his government were able to return to Kuwait. ==See also== * [[Exclusive mandate]] * [[Exilarchy]] * [[Provisional government]] * [[Shadow government (disambiguation)]] * [[Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization]] ===Lists=== * [[List of active autonomist and secessionist movements]] * [[List of historical autonomist and secessionist movements]] * [[List of historical unrecognized countries]] * [[List of territorial disputes]] * [[List of unrecognized countries]] * [[United Nations list of Non-Self-Governing Territories]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Government In Exile}} [[Category:Exile organizations]] [[Category:Government]] [[Category:Governments in exile| ]] [[cs:Exilová vláda]] [[de:Exilregierung]] [[et:Eksiilvalitsus]] [[es:Gobierno en el exilio]] [[fr:Gouvernement en exil]] [[ko:망명 정부]] [[id:Pemerintahan dalam pengasingan]] [[it:Governo in esilio]] [[he:ממשלה גולה]] [[lb:Exilregierung]] [[lt:Emigracinė vyriausybė]] [[nl:Regering in ballingschap]] [[ja:亡命政府]] [[pt:Governo no exílio]] [[ro:Guvern în exil]] [[ru:Правительство в изгнании]] [[simple:Government-in-exile]] [[sk:Exilová vláda]] [[fi:Pakolaishallitus]] [[sv:Exilregering]] [[tr:Sürgün hükümet]] [[zh-classical:流亡政府]] [[wuu:流亡政府]] [[zh:流亡政府]]
